elements.content: Coordination polymers are useful materials in different fields of applications, including the development of supramolecular electrical devices for the use of renewable energy sources. In this work, we have designed two new classes of mixed-ligand one-dimensional coordination polymers (1D CPs) [Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (1) and [Zn­(Succ)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (2) (ADC2–, acetylenedicarboxylato; Succ2–, succinato; PBT, 2-pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole) and characterized them by elemental analysis, infrared spectra (IR), single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data. In the structural motif Zn­(II) is bridged by an aliphatic dicarboxylato ligand (ADC/Succ) and two axial positions are occupied by pyridyl-N of PBT along with water coordination. ADC acts as a monodentate carboxylato-O ligand in compound 1, whereas in 2 Succ serves as a carboxylato-O,O chelator. Compounds 1 and 2 are both isostructural and construct 3D supramolecular networks by hydrogen bonds (bonding) and π···π interactions along with weak C–H···π interactions. Fascinatingly, compound 1 exhibits an ∼700 times higher Schottky barrier diode (SBD) electrical conductivity (1.31 × 10–2 S m–1) in comparison to compound 2 (1.80 × 10–5 S m–1). The impedance electrical conductivities of 1 (1.22 × 10–4 S m–1) and 2 (3.24 × 10–6 S m–1) differ significantly; in addition, the direct current conductivities are 1.08 × 10–4 S m–1 (1) and 5.55 × 10–6 S m–1 (2). To shed light on the charge transport mechanism of the compounds, the mobility, transit time, and density of states at a quasi-Fermi level have been evaluated. Linear dicarboxylato bridging with an sp-hybrid acetylene motif may be the reason for faster charge flow in 1 in comparison to the sp3 hybrid nonlinear succinato bridging compound 2.

In the structural motif Zn(II) is bridged by an aliphatic dicarboxylato ligand (ADC/Succ) and two axial positions are occupied by pyridyl-N of PBT along with water coordination. ADC acts as a monodentate carboxylato-O ligand in compound 1, whereas in 2 Succ serves as a carboxylato-O,O chelator. Compounds 1 and 2 are both isostructural and construct 3D supramolecular networks by hydrogen bonds (bonding) and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions along with weak C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Fascinatingly, compound 1 exhibits an ~700 times higher Schottky barrier diode (SBD) electrical conductivity (1.31 × 10-2 S m-1) in comparison to compound 2 (1.80 × 10-5 S m-1). The impedance electrical conductivities of 1 (1.22 × 10-4 S m-1) and 2 (3.24 × 10-6 S m-1) differ significantly; in addition, the direct current conductivities are 1.08 × 10-4 S m-1 (1) and 5.55 × 10-6 S m-1 (2). To shed light on the charge transport mechanism of the compounds, the mobility, transit time, and density of states at a quasi-Fermi level have been evaluated. Linear dicarboxylato bridging with an sp-hybrid acetylene motif may be the reason for faster charge flow in 1 in comparison to the sp3 hybrid nonlinear succinato bridging compound 2.

elements.content: Two new mixed-ligand one-dimensional coordination polymers (1D CPs) [Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (1) and [Zn­(Succ)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (2), have been designed for supramolecular electrical device application, and interestingly the conductivity value of the linear (ADC, 1) carboxylate linker based SBD has improved ∼700 times in comparison with the nonlinear (Succ, 2) based SBD.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) have gained great attention in recent times in the field of materials science due to their attractive inherent properties that lead to a variety of applications, such as magnetism, catalysis, nonlinear optics, molecular wires, and molecular sensing. In the field of material chemistry, the first principle is to transfer technology from the laboratory to the land (for potential applications). One of the focused research areas in CPs is the design of light inspired higher conducting materials to meet the challenges of the energy crisis. Thus, research in materials chemistry has been directed to fabricate electronic devices using highly conducting compounds. To improve the quality of conducting CPs, a judicious choice of metal nodes, structure-directed organic linkers, and uninterrupted π conjugation are required. The development of electroconductive materials is widely distributed in one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures. In fact, out of the hundreds of CPs, only a few exhibit recognizable electrical conductivity. A highly ordered crystal structure assists in defect-free charge transportation, and hence an improvement in electrical conductivity is observed. There are three significant charge transport mechanisms that have been noted: (i) through space usually directed by π stacking, (ii) through the covalent bonds, as in molecular wires, and (iii) through charge hopping, which operates in molecular conductors such as CPs and MOFs. The first two mechanisms are ideally based on band transport, whereas the hopping mechanism is governed by Marcus theory. The conducting properties of CPs have been influenced by the π conjugation of the linkers, the metal ion type in the nodes, and the flexibility as well as the chemical functionality of the ligands. Dicarboxylates have been equipped as “linkers” in the construction of major classes of CPs for various dimensionalities with different coordination modes and sizes. Aliphatic dicarboxylates are more flexible than aromatic dicarboxylates and have been used to design CPs. The electronic properties are influenced by the steric and electronic nature of organic linkers. Thus, the bulk electronic properties of the polymers may be harmonized by changing the linkers. The CPs synthesized from d10 metal ions (Zn2+, Cd2+) with conjugated carboxylate organic linkers are found to exhibit semiconductor properties and may be the active components in photonic and electronic devices.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) have gained great attention in recent times in the field of materials science due to their attractive inherent properties that lead to a variety of applications, such as magnetism, catalysis, nonlinear optics, molecular wires, and molecular sensing. In the field of material chemistry, the first principle is to transfer technology from the laboratory to the land (for potential applications). One of the focused research areas in CPs is the design of light inspired higher conducting materials to meet the challenges of the energy crisis. Thus, research in materials chemistry has been directed to fabricate electronic devices using highly conducting compounds. To improve the quality of conducting CPs, a judicious choice of metal nodes, structure-directed organic linkers, and uninterrupted π conjugation are required. The development of electroconductive materials is widely distributed in one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures. In fact, out of the hundreds of CPs, only a few exhibit recognizable electrical conductivity. A highly ordered crystal structure assists in defect-free charge transportation, and hence an improvement in electrical conductivity is observed. There are three significant charge transport mechanisms that have been noted: (i) through space usually directed by π stacking, (ii) through the covalent bonds, as in molecular wires, and (iii) through charge hopping, which operates in molecular conductors such as CPs and MOFs. The first two mechanisms are ideally based on band transport, whereas the hopping mechanism is governed by Marcus theory. The conducting properties of CPs have been influenced by the π conjugation of the linkers, the metal ion type in the nodes, and the flexibility as well as the chemical functionality of the ligands. Dicarboxylates have been equipped as "linkers" in the construction of major classes of CPs for various dimensionalities with different coordination modes and sizes. Aliphatic dicarboxylates are more flexible than aromatic dicarboxylates and have been used to design CPs. The electronic properties are influenced by the steric and electronic nature of organic linkers. Thus, the bulk electronic properties of the polymers may be harmonized by changing the linkers. The CPs synthesized from d10 metal ions (Zn2+, Cd2+) with conjugated carboxylate organic linkers are found to exhibit semiconductor properties and may be the active components in photonic and electronic devices.

elements.content: In this work, we have synthesized two CPs with subtle differences in structure: an aliphatic dicarboxylato ligand (ADC2–, acetylenedicarboxylato; Succ2–, succinato) bridges Zn­(II), and two axial positions are occupied by pyridyl-N of PBT (2-pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole) along with water coordination. The acetylenedicarboxylato (ADC2–) ligand acts as a monodentate carboxylato-O ligand in compound 1, and succinate serves as a carboxylato-O,O chelator in 2. The 3D supramolecular networks in these two compounds are constructed by hydrogen bonds and C–H···π interactions. These two compounds show electrical conductivity, but among them, 1 shows remarkably enhanced (∼700 times) efficiency in comparison to 2. In conjunction with the experiments, quantum mechanical calculations using DFT and TD DFT have been performed to get insight into the band gap, band positions, etc.

The acetylenedicarboxylato (ADC2-) ligand acts as a monodentate carboxylato-O ligand in compound 1, and succinate serves as a carboxylato-O,O chelator in 2. The 3D supramolecular networks in these two compounds are constructed by hydrogen bonds and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. These two compounds show electrical conductivity, but among them, 1 shows remarkably enhanced (~700 times) efficiency in comparison to 2. In conjunction with the experiments, quantum mechanical calculations using DFT and TD DFT have been performed to get insight into the band gap, band positions, etc.

2-Pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole (PBT) was synthesized and characterized by a literature method.

[Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of PBT (molecular weight 212.27, 42 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was slowly and carefully layered on a solution of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (2 mL) using 2 mL of a 1/1 (v/v) buffer solution of MeOH and H2O followed by layering of H2ADC (23 mg, 0.2 mmol) neutralized with Et3N (0.027 mL, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH (2 mL). The colorless prismatic crystals of [Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (1) were obtained after a few days (49 mg, yield 76%). Anal. Calcd for C28H20N4O6S2Zn: C, 52.71; H, 3.16; N, 8.78. Found: C, 52.57; H, 3.12; N, 8.56. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1609 (−CN), 1556 νas(COO–),1319 νsys(COO–), 3252 ν­(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

Experimental Section

Synthesis

2-Pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole (PBT) was synthesized and characterized by a literature method. 

[Zn(ADC)(PBT)2(H2O)2] n  (1)

A solution of PBT (molecular weight 212.27, 42 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was slowly and carefully layered on a solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (2 mL) using 2 mL of a 1/1 (v/v) buffer solution of MeOH and H2O followed by layering of H2ADC (23 mg, 0.2 mmol) neutralized with Et3N (0.027 mL, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH (2 mL). The colorless prismatic crystals of [Zn(ADC)(PBT)2(H2O)2] n  (1) were obtained after a few days (49 mg, yield 76%). Anal. Calcd for C28H20N4O6S2Zn: C, 52.71; H, 3.16; N, 8.78. Found: C, 52.57; H, 3.12; N, 8.56. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1609 (-CN), 1556 νas(COO-),1319 νsys(COO-), 3252 ν(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

Found: C, 53.99; H, 3.58; N, 9.01. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1622 (−CN), 1551 νas(COO), 1397 νsys(COO), 3176 ν­(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Single-crystal data and experimental information on data collection and structure refinement are reported in . Two good-shaped single crystals of 1 (0.18 × 0.18 × 0.15 mm) were used for data collection via a Rigaku FRX RA generator (confocal optic) with P200 detector, and a crystal of 2 (0.4 × 0.09 × 0.04 mm) was used to collect data with a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Least-squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl ranges −20 ≤ h ≤ 21, – 37 ≤ k ≤ 37, – 22 ≤ l ≤ 20 (1) and −32 ≤ h ≤ 32, – 6 ≤ k ≤ 7, – 17 ≤ l ≤ 19 (2) were used to evaluate the crystal-orientation matrices and unit cell parameters. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The collected data (I > 2σ­(I)) were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption correction was made with SADABS. Full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were carried out using SHELXL-2014/7 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms, and complex 1 was further refined with the Olex2 1.2-alpha crystallographic package. All calculations were carried out using the SHELXL 2014/7, SHELXS 2014/7, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 programs.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal data and experimental information on data collection and structure refinement are reported in . Two good-shaped single crystals of 1 (0.18 × 0.18 × 0.15 mm) were used for data collection via a Rigaku FRX RA generator (confocal optic) with P200 detector, and a crystal of 2 (0.4 × 0.09 × 0.04 mm) was used to collect data with a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Least-squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl ranges -20 ≤ h ≤ 21, - 37 ≤ k ≤ 37, - 22 ≤ l ≤ 20 (1) and -32 ≤ h ≤ 32, - 6 ≤ k ≤ 7, - 17 ≤ l ≤ 19 (2) were used to evaluate the crystal-orientation matrices and unit cell parameters. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The collected data (I > 2σ(I)) were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption correction was made with SADABS. Full-matrix least-squares refinements on F  2  were carried out using SHELXL-2014/7 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms, and complex 1 was further refined with the Olex2 1.2-alpha crystallographic package. All calculations were carried out using the SHELXL 2014/7, SHELXS 2014/7, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 programs.

The reason for A-level alerts and the data analyses are described in the Supporting Information.

The optimized structures of 1 and 2 were performed by using density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP level. The theoretical calculations were done with the Gaussian 09 program package with the aid of the GaussView visualization program. For C, H, N, and O the 6-31G­(d) basis set was used, and the LanL2DZ basis set with effective core potential without any symmetry constraint was employed for Zn. The vibrational frequency calculations were evaluated for these two compounds to ensure that the optimized geometries represented the local minima and that there were only positive eigenvalues. The single crystals of X-ray coordinates of 1 and 2 were used in the calculations. Vertical electronic excitations based on B3LYP optimized geometries were computed using the time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) formalism in DMSO using a conductorlike polarizable continuum model (CPCM) to consign the low-lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra. Gauss Sum was used to calculate the contributions of various functional groups in each molecular orbital. The electronic structure and related properties of the compounds were obtained from DFT computation studies.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

The optimized structures of 1 and 2 were performed by using density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP level. The theoretical calculations were done with the Gaussian 09 program package with the aid of the GaussView visualization program. For C, H, N, and O the 6-31G(d) basis set was used, and the LanL2DZ basis set with effective core potential without any symmetry constraint was employed for Zn. The vibrational frequency calculations were evaluated for these two compounds to ensure that the optimized geometries represented the local minima and that there were only positive eigenvalues. The single crystals of X-ray coordinates of 1 and 2 were used in the calculations. Vertical electronic excitations based on B3LYP optimized geometries were computed using the time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) formalism in DMSO using a conductorlike polarizable continuum model (CPCM) to consign the low-lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra. Gauss Sum was used to calculate the contributions of various functional groups in each molecular orbital. The electronic structure and related properties of the compounds were obtained from DFT computation studies.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P21/n with Z = 16, and compound 2 crystallizes in the same system and space group C2/c with Z = 4. The asymmetric unit in 1 has a distorted-octahedral geometry with a ZnO4N2 coordination sphere. The structure (, 1) shows that two ADC2– ligands act as monodentate carboxylato-O donors to Zn­(II) (Zn(1)–O(161), 2.127(3) Å; Zn(1)–O(198), 2.158(3) Å), two H2O molecules occupy equatorial sites (Zn(1)–O(16), 2.104(3) Å; Zn(1)–O(17), 2.092(4) Å), and two pyridyl-N groups from two PBT ligands (Zn(1)–N(1), 2.159(4) Å; Zn(1)–N(21), 2.158(4) Å) take axial positions (). In compound 2 the Zn­(II) ion is bridged by a chelating succinato-O,O ligands (Succ2–) and two axial positions are occupied by pyridyl-N groups of PBT along with water coordination (, 2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system and space group P21/n with Z = 16, and compound 2 crystallizes in the same system and space group C2/c with Z = 4. The asymmetric unit in 1 has a distorted-octahedral geometry with a ZnO4N2 coordination sphere. The structure (, 1) shows that two ADC2- ligands act as monodentate carboxylato-O donors to Zn(II) (Zn(1)-O(161), 2.127(3) Å; Zn(1)-O(198), 2.158(3) Å), two H2O molecules occupy equatorial sites (Zn(1)-O(16), 2.104(3) Å; Zn(1)-O(17), 2.092(4) Å), and two pyridyl-N groups from two PBT ligands (Zn(1)-N(1), 2.159(4) Å; Zn(1)-N(21), 2.158(4) Å) take axial positions (). In compound 2 the Zn(II) ion is bridged by a chelating succinato-O,O ligands (Succ2-) and two axial positions are occupied by pyridyl-N groups of PBT along with water coordination (, 2).

elements.content: Therefore, 1D zigzag chains aggregate through hydrogen-bonding and π···π interactions (b, Table S2) to assemble the 2D architecture of compound 2. These cooperative hydrogen-bonding () and π···π interactions () fabricate a 3D supramolecular arrangement for both 1 and 2. To verify the thermal stability of the compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were executed with powdered samples within the temperature range of 23–600 °C under an N2 atmosphere. The TGA analysis reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ∼112 °C, whereas compound 2 is thermally stable up to ∼133 °C (Figure S4). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been performed at room temperature, and all of the main peaks of PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and 2 matched well with those simulated from single-crystal data, signifying the phase purity of the bulk (Figure S5). To authenticate the morphology and elemental analysis of our synthesized compounds 1 and 2, we performed SEM image and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses via field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JEOL, JSM-6700F) (Figure S6 and Table S3).

The TGA analysis reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ~112 °C, whereas compound 2 is thermally stable up to ~133 °C (Figure S4). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been performed at room temperature, and all of the main peaks of PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and 2 matched well with those simulated from single-crystal data, signifying the phase purity of the bulk (Figure S5). To authenticate the morphology and elemental analysis of our synthesized compounds 1 and 2, we performed SEM image and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses via field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JEOL, JSM-6700F) (Figure S6 and Table S3).

elements.content: The optical properties of the synthesized materials were measured by UV–vis absorption spectra. The inset of represents the normalized absorption spectra of compounds 1 and 2 deposited as thin films by preparing a good dispersion in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) medium, which were recorded in the wavelength region of 200–800 nm. Energy absorption is observed in the UV regions 337 and 315 nm for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. The optical band energy gaps of 1 and 2 have been determined by the Tauc equation () α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap energy, h is Planck’s constant, ν is the frequency of light, the exponent n is the electron transition process dependent constant (for a direct transition n = 1/2), and A is a constant which is considered to be 1 for the general case.

By extrapolation of the linear region of the plot (α h ν)2 vs h ν plots, the values for the direct optical band gap energies for 1 and 2 were evaluated as 3.67 and 3.93 eV, respectively. elements.content: An impedance spectroscopy (IS) study was performed in the frequency range 40 Hz to 10 MHz at room temperature. a shows the Nyquist plot for the two compounds under dark conditions. The higher frequency semicircular arc depicts the bulk contribution, and the intermediate or low-frequency semicircular arc represents the grain boundary or electrode-specimen effect. The intercept of the semicircular arc on real axis Z′ demonstrates the bulk resistance R b (dc resistance) of our synthesized compounds. From a it is clearly seen that compound 1 has resistance lower than that of compound 2. The lower resistance signifies the better possibility of charge transfer. b shows the ac conductivity plots for 1 and 2. At a lower region of frequency, the extrapolation of the Y axis gives the value of dc conductivity (σ dc), which is attributed to the long-range translational motion of the charge carriers.

elements.content: In the high-frequency region, the term Aω s is responsible for the frequency-dependent behavior and the dispersion nature. The frequency dependence of ac conductivity (σ ac) may be described for free and bound carriers. The dependence of the conductivity on frequency can be expressed by the power law equation () σ ( ω ) = σ dc + σ ac where σ(ω) is the total conductivity, σ dc is the dc conductivity, and σ ac is the ac conductivity. In the high-frequency region, the increase in conductivity is described through Jonscher’s power law, defined in : σ ac = σ dc [ 1 + ( ω ω H ) s ] where s is the dimensionless frequency component, ω (=2πf) is the angular frequency, and ω H is the hopping frequency of the charge carrier. At room temperature, the dc conductivity (σ dc) of 1 (1.22 × 10–4 S m–1) is about 375 times higher than that of 2 (3.24 × 10–6 S m–1 ).

elements.content: The band gap of compounds 1 and 2 lies well within the semiconducting limit, which has prompted us to further check the electrical conductivity and its possible application in a metal–semiconductor heterostructure such as a Schottky barrier diode (SBD). Hence, for a better understanding of the charge transport phenomena, an electrical characterization was carried out for thin-film devices of well-dispersed solutions of compounds deposited on top of ITO-coated glass substrates. To analyze the electrical properties, current–voltage (I–V) measurements of 1- and 2-based thin-film devices were performed in the range ±2.0 V with a Keithley 2635B source meter under dark conditions. The current–voltage characteristic curve in exhibits nonlinear rectifying behavior, which is the signature of the Schottky diode. The rectification ratios (i.e., on/off ratios) of the devices under dark conditions were measured as 59.41 and 38.68 for 1 and 2, respectively. A logarithmic presentation of I as a function of V is shown in the inset of .
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Characterization

The band gap of compounds 1 and 2 lies well within the semiconducting limit, which has prompted us to further check the electrical conductivity and its possible application in a metal-semiconductor heterostructure such as a Schottky barrier diode (SBD). Hence, for a better understanding of the charge transport phenomena, an electrical characterization was carried out for thin-film devices of well-dispersed solutions of compounds deposited on top of ITO-coated glass substrates. To analyze the electrical properties, current-voltage (I-V) measurements of 1- and 2-based thin-film devices were performed in the range ±2.0 V with a Keithley 2635B source meter under dark conditions. The current-voltage characteristic curve in  exhibits nonlinear rectifying behavior, which is the signature of the Schottky diode. The rectification ratios (i.e., on/off ratios) of the devices under dark conditions were measured as 59.41 and 38.68 for 1 and 2, respectively. A logarithmic presentation of I as a function of V is shown in the inset of .

elements.content: The barrier heights of 1 and 2 have been obtained as 0.55 and 0.63 eV, respectively. It is very important to note that the rectification ratio of the 1-based device increased whereas the barrier height decreased in comparison to 2-based devices. Thus, compound 1 is expected to be the better candidate for a fast switching device. To get a better insight into the charge transport phenomena, we investigated the I–V curves in detail. The current conduction mechanism is governed by the power law (I ∞ V m ), where m is the slope of the I vs V curve. The characteristic I–V curves () under dark conditions on the logarithmic scale revealed that they can be differentiated in two slopes for compounds 1 and 2. The two regions have slopes of nearly 1 and 2. In region I, when the slope is ∼1, the current follows the relation I ∞ V, which refers to the Ohmic regime.

elements.content: The I–V characteristics in this region can be attributed to the thermionic emission of current. In region II, the slope is about 2, where the current is proportional to V 2 . In this region, the current originating from space charge is designated as the space charge limit current (SCLC) mechanism by discrete trapping level. If the amounts of injected carriers are greater than those of the background carriers, the injected carriers spread and create a space charge field. The currents are controlled by this field and are known as SCLC. The device performance greatly depends on the mobility and transit time of the carriers. elements.content: The density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level was determined from the SCLC region of I–V characteristics using the den Boer method ( and ) N ′ ( E F ) = 2 ε 0 ε r ( V 2 − V 1 ) q d 2 Δ E F Δ E F = k T ln ( I 2 V 1 I 1 V 2 ) where N′(E F) is the DOS, d is the thickness of the film, E F is the quasi-Fermi level, T is the room temperature in Kelvin, and V 1, V 2 and I 1, I 2 are different voltages and currents applied to the diode in the space charge region. A longer transit time generally indicates the occurrence of a greater number of trapping states, but for compound 1 the transit time is decreased due to the higher carrier mobility. Therefore, from all the measured values given in , it is very distinct that the device fabricated by compound 1 is better than that by 2.

To generate a Schottky electrical contact, the lattice matching and deformation potentials have been used. The deformation commonly refers to the difference between the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energies: i.e., band gap (ΔE = E LUMO – E HOMO, eV). In 1 and 2 the absolute deformation potentials (ADPs) are used to determine the band gap. These polymers have an organic and an inorganic moiety; therefore, the band gap may be influenced by the electronic contributions of both. In compounds 1 and 2, the Zn has a d10 electronic configuration; the band edges are often defined by electronic states on the organic moiety along with the geometric strain of the network. The structural agreement has also been verified by comparing the bond distances and angles between the DFT optimized and X-ray determined structures. DFT optimization of the structure of the coordination motifs of 1 and 2 has been used to calculate ΔE (the difference in energy of the HOMO and LUMO) (compounds 1 and 2) (), which may match with the band gap obtained from a Tauc plot (). The energy of MOs is increased in 2 in comparison to compound 1, which may be due to electron drift in the metal coordination sphere, which follows the experimental results (Figure S9 and Table S4).
elements.clean_text:
DFT Computation and Band Gap

To generate a Schottky electrical contact, the lattice matching and deformation potentials have been used. The deformation commonly refers to the difference between the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energies: i.e., band gap (ΔE = E LUMO - E HOMO, eV). In 1 and 2 the absolute deformation potentials (ADPs) are used to determine the band gap. These polymers have an organic and an inorganic moiety; therefore, the band gap may be influenced by the electronic contributions of both. In compounds 1 and 2, the Zn has a d10 electronic configuration; the band edges are often defined by electronic states on the organic moiety along with the geometric strain of the network. The structural agreement has also been verified by comparing the bond distances and angles between the DFT optimized and X-ray determined structures. DFT optimization of the structure of the coordination motifs of 1 and 2 has been used to calculate ΔE (the difference in energy of the HOMO and LUMO) (compounds 1 and 2) (), which may match with the band gap obtained from a Tauc plot (). The energy of MOs is increased in 2 in comparison to compound 1, which may be due to electron drift in the metal coordination sphere, which follows the experimental results (Figure S9 and Table S4).

elements.content: The calculated (TD DFT) transitions HOMO-1 → LUMO+1 (λ, 335 nm; f, 0.0494); HOMO-4 → LUMO+2 (λ, 256.04 nm; f, 0.2110), etc. have been assigned as ILCT charge transfers for 1. In 2 the composition differs significantly, i.e., HOMO-1 → LUMO (λ, 323.41 nm; f, 0.5675); the HOMO-9 → LUMO+1 transition (λ, 270.44 nm; f, 0.0307) is also an ILCT charge transfer transition (Figures S9 and S10 and Tables S5 and S7). A small increment in the calculated band gap may be assigned to the geometry factor, which has not been considered in the use of calculation of a single motif. The contribution of an acid part in compound 1 exists in HOMO-4 → LUMO+2 and HOMO-5 → LUMO+1 having lower energy, in comparison to that in compound 2, where the acid part exists in HOMO-9 → LUMO+1 and HOMO-15 → LUMO; this shows that the band gap in 1 is lower than that in compound 2 ( Figure S10 and Table S6 ). This direction is also seen in the HOMO → LUMO band gaps in both compounds. As a result, compound 1 shows more conductivity in comparison to that of 2.

In 2 the composition differs significantly, i.e., HOMO-1 → LUMO (λ, 323.41 nm; f, 0.5675); the HOMO-9 → LUMO+1 transition (λ, 270.44 nm; f, 0.0307) is also an ILCT charge transfer transition (Figures S9 and S10 and Tables S5 and S7). A small increment in the calculated band gap may be assigned to the geometry factor, which has not been considered in the use of calculation of a single motif. The contribution of an acid part in compound 1 exists in HOMO-4 → LUMO+2 and HOMO-5 → LUMO+1 having lower energy, in comparison to that in compound 2, where the acid part exists in HOMO-9 → LUMO+1 and HOMO-15 → LUMO; this shows that the band gap in 1 is lower than that in compound 2 ( Figure S10 and Table S6 ). elements.content: In summary, we have successfully constructed two 1D coordination polymers (CPs) of Zn­(II) with PBT (2-pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole and two aliphatic dicarboxylato ligands, ADC2– (acetylenedicarboxylato) and Succ2– (succinato). The 1D polymeric chains herein stack together by a combination of H-bonding, π···π, and weak C–H···π interactions to form 3D supramolecular aggregated structures. From impedance spectral analysis it can be seen that compound 1 has lower resistance in comparison to 2, which implies that 1 exhibits higher electrical conductivity in comparison to 2. Space charge limited current (SCLC) theory has been incorporated for a better understanding of charge transport phenomena through the metal–semiconductor junction for 1- and 2-based Schottky devices. However, the 1-based metal–semiconductor hetero structure shows improved charge transport properties in comparison to 2-based devices due to the higher carrier mobility and reduced transit time. The linear dicarboxylato bridging with an sp hybrid acetylene motif may be the reason for faster charge flow in 1 in comparison to the sp3 hybrid nonlinear succinato bridging in 2. Thus, these kinds of materials can pave the way for a very promising future in device applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully constructed two 1D coordination polymers (CPs) of Zn(II) with PBT (2-pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole and two aliphatic dicarboxylato ligands, ADC2- (acetylenedicarboxylato) and Succ2- (succinato). The 1D polymeric chains herein stack together by a combination of H-bonding, π⋅⋅⋅π, and weak C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions to form 3D supramolecular aggregated structures. From impedance spectral analysis it can be seen that compound 1 has lower resistance in comparison to 2, which implies that 1 exhibits higher electrical conductivity in comparison to 2. Space charge limited current (SCLC) theory has been incorporated for a better understanding of charge transport phenomena through the metal-semiconductor junction for 1- and 2-based Schottky devices. However, the 1-based metal-semiconductor hetero structure shows improved charge transport properties in comparison to 2-based devices due to the higher carrier mobility and reduced transit time. The linear dicarboxylato bridging with an sp hybrid acetylene motif may be the reason for faster charge flow in 1 in comparison to the sp3 hybrid nonlinear succinato bridging in 2. Thus, these kinds of materials can pave the way for a very promising future in device applications.

cln_elements.content:
2-Pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole (PBT) was synthesized and characterized by a literature method.

[Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of PBT (molecular weight 212.27, 42 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was slowly and carefully layered on a solution of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (2 mL) using 2 mL of a 1/1 (v/v) buffer solution of MeOH and H2O followed by layering of H2ADC (23 mg, 0.2 mmol) neutralized with Et3N (0.027 mL, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH (2 mL). The colorless prismatic crystals of [Zn­(ADC)­(PBT)2(H2O)2] n (1) were obtained after a few days (49 mg, yield 76%). Anal. Calcd for C28H20N4O6S2Zn: C, 52.71; H, 3.16; N, 8.78. Found: C, 52.57; H, 3.12; N, 8.56. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1609 (−CN), 1556 νas(COO–),1319 νsys(COO–), 3252 ν­(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

[Zn­(Succ)­(PBT)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

2 was synthesized by a procedure identical with that adopted for 1, by layering a solution of PBT in MeOH over Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) in water followed by H2Succ. Yellowish rectangular shaped crystals of [Zn­(Succ)­(PBT)2(H2O)] n (2) were obtained after a few days (43 mg, yield 68%). Anal. Calcd for C28H22N4O5S2Zn: C, 53.89; H, 3.55; N, 8.98. Found: C, 53.99; H, 3.58; N, 9.01. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1622 (−CN), 1551 νas(COO), 1397 νsys(COO), 3176 ν­(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

Experimental Section

Synthesis

2-Pyridin-4-ylbenzothiazole (PBT) was synthesized and characterized by a literature method. 

[Zn(ADC)(PBT)2(H2O)2] n  (1)

A solution of PBT (molecular weight 212.27, 42 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was slowly and carefully layered on a solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (2 mL) using 2 mL of a 1/1 (v/v) buffer solution of MeOH and H2O followed by layering of H2ADC (23 mg, 0.2 mmol) neutralized with Et3N (0.027 mL, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH (2 mL). The colorless prismatic crystals of [Zn(ADC)(PBT)2(H2O)2] n  (1) were obtained after a few days (49 mg, yield 76%). Anal. Calcd for C28H20N4O6S2Zn: C, 52.71; H, 3.16; N, 8.78. Found: C, 52.57; H, 3.12; N, 8.56. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1609 (-CN), 1556 νas(COO-),1319 νsys(COO-), 3252 ν(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

[Zn(Succ)(PBT)2(H2O)] n  (2)

Yellowish rectangular shaped crystals of [Zn(Succ)(PBT)2(H2O)] n  (2) were obtained after a few days (43 mg, yield 68%). Anal. Calcd for C28H22N4O5S2Zn: C, 53.89; H, 3.55; N, 8.98. Found: C, 53.99; H, 3.58; N, 9.01. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1622 (-CN), 1551 νas(COO), 1397 νsys(COO), 3176 ν(H2O) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
Therefore, 1D zigzag chains aggregate through hydrogen-bonding and π···π interactions (b, Table S2) to assemble the 2D architecture of compound 2. These cooperative hydrogen-bonding () and π···π interactions () fabricate a 3D supramolecular arrangement for both 1 and 2. To verify the thermal stability of the compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were executed with powdered samples within the temperature range of 23–600 °C under an N2 atmosphere. The TGA analysis reveals that compound 1 is stable up to ∼112 °C, whereas compound 2 is thermally stable up to ∼133 °C (Figure S4). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been performed at room temperature, and all of the main peaks of PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and 2 matched well with those simulated from single-crystal data, signifying the phase purity of the bulk (Figure S5). To authenticate the morphology and elemental analysis of our synthesized compounds 1 and 2, we performed SEM image and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses via field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JEOL, JSM-6700F) (Figure S6 and Table S3).

UV–Vis and Impedance Spectroscopy StudyOptical Characterization

The optical properties of the synthesized materials were measured by UV–vis absorption spectra. The inset of represents the normalized absorption spectra of compounds 1 and 2 deposited as thin films by preparing a good dispersion in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) medium, which were recorded in the wavelength region of 200–800 nm. Energy absorption is observed in the UV regions 337 and 315 nm for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. The optical band energy gaps of 1 and 2 have been determined by the Tauc equation () α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap energy, h is Planck’s constant, ν is the frequency of light, the exponent n is the electron transition process dependent constant (for a direct transition n = 1/2), and A is a constant which is considered to be 1 for the general case.

The (α h ν)2 vs h ν plots of the synthesized compounds are portrayed in . By extrapolation of the linear region of the plot (α h ν)2 vs h ν plots, the values for the direct optical band gap energies for 1 and 2 were evaluated as 3.67 and 3.93 eV, respectively. To further verify the optical band gap energy for compounds 1 and 2, we used the Kubelka–Munk function (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). The measured band gap energy values from the Tauc equation and Kubelka–Munk equation are very close for compounds 1 (3.61 eV) and 2 (3.92 eV).

The optical properties of the synthesized materials were measured by UV-vis absorption spectra.
